At that time, the World-Honored One went back and forth seven times, and then said:

Then the World-Honored One spoke of himself:

The five grains ripened and the people were at ease. With the Dharma, he widely transformed and caused the illnesses of desires in their minds to all become pure. He established them in the Way, and all the people were greatly delighted.

When the people heard this, all those who were sick went to the prince. Everyone in the country, young and old, rejoiced and praised his virtues. No one went to other doctors or slighted other doctors;

At that time, throughout JambudvÄ«pa, the people were afflicted with epidemics and famine. Even with all the medical treatments, they could not be cured, and the number of people dying increased day by day.
The king was greatly worried and summoned all the doctors to ask about the treatment.
At that time, there was a doctor who was jealous of the prince. He thought to himself:
'Now this prince is my enemy, and I have finally found an opportunity.'
He then said to the king:
'There is another place that should be thoroughly searched. The king can then try it.'
He immediately left and returned the next day, saying to the king:
'I have searched one place. If the king can take the medicine, his many illnesses will surely be cured.'
The king then said to him:
'What kind of medicine is needed? Please try to explain it.'
The doctor replied to the king:

'It must be the blood of someone who has been benevolent and compassionate towards sentient beings since birth, never giving rise to an angry mind, mixed with medicine and taken. His two eyes are needed to dispel the ghost, and only then will the many illnesses be cured.'
The king then replied:
'Someone who has never given rise to anger since birth is truly rare.

The prince heard this and said to his father, the king:
'This matter is easy, not difficult to obtain.'
The prince said to the king:
'I am the king's son. Since I was born, I have never been angry or harmed others, always compassionate to all without any evil appearance.
My body is impermanent and not solid, and before long, I will also die;

The king then replied:
'I have no son. I prayed to the various gods, the sun, moon, stars, the four mountains and five peaks, and then obtained a son.

The prince then said to his father, the king:
'I seek the Way of the Buddha. Now, I offer my blood to the sentient beings, and with this merit, I will fully understand the teachings of the Buddha's scriptures.
I now give this flesh eye to sentient beings. With this merit, I will attain the eye of wisdom of the TathÄgata and will be the true guide for all.

The king wept sadly and replied to the crown prince:
'I would rather abandon the position of king, but I truly cannot let go of my pitiable son.'
Then the crown prince knelt for a long time with his palms joined and said to the father king:
'Now I seek the unsurpassed true path. If I cherish this stinking and filthy body, how can I attain the profound and wonderful Dharma of the TathÄgata's wisdom?

The father king remained silent and had nothing more to say.
The doctor said to the king:

Then the prince pierced his arm to draw blood and made a vow, saying:

'With this blood, I will cure the illnesses of all people. I will use this merit to accomplish the unsurpassed, true path. If I truly become a Buddha, then all sentient beings who take this medicine will be cured of their illnesses.'
He then mixed the blood with medicine and gave it to the sick people, and their illnesses were all cured.
The doctor then said to the king:
'Those who were sick and took this medicine were all cured. This is a matter that can be seen right before your eyes, so it cannot be disbelieved.'

At that time, the eighty-four thousand minor kings and subjects of JambudvÄ«pa heard that the prince had gouged out his own eyes out of compassion for all, and none of them did not weep with grief. They all came and gathered, knelt for a long time with their hands clasped, and said to the prince:

Your compassion for all beings, before long you will attain Buddhahood, please do not destroy your eyes yourself.'
Then the Prince admonished and apologized to the kings, ministers, and people:
'Now, with these flesh and blood eyes of mine, I will remove the illnesses of the masses. I hold this merit and virtue to seek Buddhahood.
When I attain Buddhahood, I will remove your bodily illnesses and mental illnesses. Do not go against my unsurpassed resolve for the Way.'
At that time, upon hearing these words, the kings and all the ministers and people remained silent.
Then the Prince ordered his attendants:
'Set up the surgical instruments, I wish to gouge out my eyes.'
He said to the attendants:

The attendants all declined, saying they could not do it.
Then the doctor who was jealous of the Prince replied:

The prince was delighted and said,
'Excellent!
' He held out the knife and said to the doctor,

So he removed one eye and placed it in the prince's palm.
Then the prince made a vow, saying,

'Now I offer this flesh eye to sentient beings, not seeking a wheel-turning sage king, not seeking a demon king, not seeking the pleasures of form, sound, smell, taste, and touch of Brahma, but using this merit to seek the unsurpassed true path, enabling me to attain the eye of omniscience, and to become a great doctor for the immeasurable sentient beings in the ten directions, removing all sentient beings' physical illnesses and mental illnesses, and bestowing the eye of wisdom upon sentient beings.'
Having said this, he then placed the eye on the table, saying,
'If it is as I wish, may all sentient beings' illnesses be cured.'
His parents, upon seeing this, immediately fainted. After a long while, they regained consciousness;

Just as he was about to raise his sword to gouge out his other eye, at that moment the trichiliocosm shook greatly, and the gods of the three realms all came down. Then, Indra came before the prince and asked him, saying:

At that time, the World-Honored One joyfully smiled, and five-colored light emerged from his mouth, with a thousand and a hundred wonders. Hearing these words, the king was moved and unhappy. He then praised him, saying:

At that time, the brahmin waited for the king to go out, stood by the side of the road, and praised the white elephant, speaking a verse, saying:

Ä€nanda knelt before the Buddha and said:

Ä€nanda said to the Buddha:

The Venerable Ä€nanda and the entire assembly, hearing what the Buddha said, were all greatly delighted, circumambulated the Buddha three times, and bowed their heads in reverence.

When the chief minister and his wife heard that the Buddha was outside, they were overjoyed and immediately went out to welcome him. They bowed at the Buddha's feet and prepared seats for him. They invited the Buddha to sit and offered him delicious food.
After the World-Honored One had finished his meal, the chief minister and his wife personally took water and washed the World-Honored One's hands.

Then, after the TathÄgata had washed his hands and rinsed his mouth, he expounded the sÅ«tras for them. He praised the virtue of giving and the blessings of upholding the precepts, saying that in the heavens and among humans, one naturally receives noble and wealthy rewards with boundless happiness and joy.
Although one may be highly respected and indulge in desires, one cannot escape the sufferings of the three evil paths.

In the hells, one is burned by fire, boiled in water, on knife mountains, sword trees, fire carts, and charcoal pits, cut and sawed to pieces, with extreme cruelty and pain, too much to describe. The suffering of hungry ghosts is that their bodies are emaciated, their stomachs are huge, their throats are as thin as needle holes, their bones and joints clack together, and their entire bodies are on fire. For hundreds of thousands of years, they do not hear the names of water and grain, and their hunger and thirst are so severe that it cannot be described.

The suffering of animals is that they are tigers, wolves, lions, snakes, pythons, vipers, and scorpions, harming each other, devouring each other. In the three evil paths, evil thoughts are rampant, and there is no good intention as small as a hair, rolling in bitter suffering without a time to escape.
Only by abandoning desires and contemplating the true meaning can one escape the many bitter sufferings.

The body in the three realms all has suffering. All suffering arises from habit. Due to the habits of desires and the defilements of the three poisons, the retribution of various practices leads to various sufferings.

Cutting off the three poisons and extinguishing desires, then there are no more practices. When all practices are exhausted, one does not receive a body. When there is no body, the myriad sufferings cease.
To exhaust desires and all the bonds of practice, one should only contemplate the eightfold correct path.
After the Buddha spoke this Dharma for the elder and his wife, they joyfully leaped and entered the four noble truths. They attained the path of stream-entry right in front of the Buddha.
Then the couple regarded the home as a prison and saw desires as fire. They had no fondness for love and affection. They knelt for a long time and said to the Buddha:
We wish to become monks.
The Buddha assented.
Their beards and hair fell out by themselves, and Dharma robes covered their bodies. The husband became a monk, and the wife became a nun. They both followed the Buddha to the monastery.

At that time, the bhiká¹£us praised the TathÄgata's spiritual powers and wisdom, and also praised the two arhats:
How wondrous and extraordinary!
Being in a venerable and prosperous position, one is able to let go of one's noble and prosperous status. For a young wife to abandon desires and pleasures is extremely difficult.

After the dragon king left, the queen sat and contemplated the events of her past lives. She remembered her past life as a human, when she violated the precepts and now fell into the realm of dragons. She immediately became unhappy and tears flowed from her eyes.
The attending maidservants saw her unhappiness and all asked her:

The queen replied:

That is why I am unhappy.
She asked the maidservants:
